posts.name: יהלי
posts.cooked:
good morning\noon\afternoon\evening whatever it may be. I’m going to post a weird query that has been itching for a long time: in the teams I have been a part of, we have been using aluminum hex axles for dead axels exclusively in some instances: steel hex axles. of course , we suffered issues of bending at high loads. I have been seeing many teams using aluminum tubes (such as versarollers) in order to support high load arms\mechanisms: but I haven’t seen many resources online that show how to use them efficiently on frc robots. so here is the question: do you have any resources regarding the use of these tubes? maybe as standoffs \ dead axels. and preferably on fixing them to rotations. I have a couple solutions in mind but would love to see what other teams do.

thanks in advance!

posts.name: Lexeo
posts.cooked: Rev has some pretty good resources here. Maybe they will help.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
I’m happy to detail our use of 7/8" OD tubing during the 2023 season for our arm at some point today after work in more detail. Here’s the quick TL/DR:

Alum round tubing is awesome for dead axle arms

7/8" OD tubing works really well with COTS sprockets because you can buy bushings from McMaster with 1.125 OD

Tube nuts are decidedly less awesome for support a high torque pivot, they can and will fail

posts.name: יהלי

COTS

interesting. i would love to hear more! i actually looked at the rev page and saw the tube nuts and though it was the correct solution, but if you think otherwise i would love to hear. only when you have time ofcourse!

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked:
Nick.kremer:

Tube nuts are decidedly less awesome for support a high torque pivot, they can and will fail

Any time I use a tube nut in a load-bearing situation I always have other components that take the radial load on the tube. I’m a big fan of 1/4" polycarb for these pieces as it’s lightweight but still has the surface area for improved support. The image below has two pieces of polycarb on the outside of a 2x1 tube that the round dead axle tube goes through and a 1/16" plate with a 1/4-20 clearance hole in it that retains the dead axle tube axially (and provides a place for the bolt to mount to). The tube nut sees almost no radial load this way. In the below example I have two 1/4" polycarb plates, but in the past I’ve run a single one per side with the opposing end just being the 1/16" aluminum plate and that’s worked fine as well, all depends on the load you expect.

image 527×686 20.4 KB

image 527×686 20.4 KB

image 527×686 20.4 KB

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
While I don’t have any issues with teams using tube axles for high-load mechanisms, I would also suggest that if you’re bending hex shaft, particularly steel hex shaft, you’re probably doing something wrong.

In my 18 years in FRC, the only times we’ve ever bent a hex shaft is when it’s on an end-effector (IE, something that takes impacts), or when the shaft was poorly supported. There’s not much you can do about the former, other than having lots of spares (and impacts will affect tube shafts too), but in the case of the later issue, supporting the shaft with additional bearings, preferably closer to the load, and using hex hubs where you interface with arm components (to maximize interface surface area), can go a long way to alleviate these issues.

It might be helpful to see specific examples of mechanisms you’re having trouble with, there might be simple solutions that don’t require huge changes to your existing build methodologies.

link_counts.title: QTY 4 - The Thrifty Hub - Half Inch Hex

posts.name: Andrew Torrance

In 2019 we had an arm with the shoulder and wrist shaft made of 1/2" thunderhex and it was fine because the span was very short (~6" long) and the shaft was supported in holes of a billet aluminum yoke piece of the carriage, not just held in place through face-contact-friction by bolts on the ends. image 1035×744 76.1 KB

posts.name: Crystal
posts.cooked:
Nick.kremer:

Tube nuts are decidedly less awesome for support a high torque pivot, they can and will fail

Tube nuts are great for what they are supposed to be doing - they have never been intended for or appropriate for supporting the weight of a tube / arm. If you are supporting a tube through just the bolt that threads into a star nut - you’re basically throwing away the benefit of using the tube as an axle. It’s not even the star nut’s fault at that point, you’re basically using the bolt as your arm’s axle and just using the tube as a big spacer rather than as a structural member at that point.

What star nuts are great for is for retaining stuff that bolts to the end of the tube, similar to the tapped hole you might find on the end of a drive hex shaft. Andrew’s post has a great example, but you can do a number of different things here. I like to use an oversized washer and a small spacer that goes around the outside of the tube to react against the structure for retention. The important thing is, the actual structure bearing the load of the tube axle is the material that the tube axle (or its bushings) passes through.

If you don’t wanna use star nuts for this, lots of other options out there. Shaft collars are kinda heavy at that size but are perfectly suited for this job. A press-fit endcap could be hammered into the tube to create a threaded hole connection to stuff outside of it, similar to a star nut. You could even use giant snap rings if you have a lathe to groove your tube with.

posts.name: יהלי
posts.cooked: so also keeping the span short is a good solution I guess. it was always counter intuitive to me that shorter axles would do a better job, becasue i though “the more span you have, the marrier” (more span to carry load i guess, but in hindsight it just means there is more material that can be bent)

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
I’m going to disagree slightly, tubes are good because are strong under bending, usually from a radial load somewhere in between two supported ends. Statics shows that you don’t actually need to hold a bending moment at the ends of the tubes, and you won’t have any significant bending load unless you have a very rigid joint which a tube nut is not. Most tube nuts are certainly not designed for for radial or moment loading, but the bolt is not going to be the first thing to go.

We’ve also had tube nuts fail just from tightening a bolt and washer into them. They spun in the tube. Personally I haven’t seen a tube nut application I like since I left the furniture industry, but if they’re working for other people go for it.

More specifically, for a given concentrated load, the stress of a beam or shaft’s deflection will increase linearly with length while the deflection increases cubically with length. For a given applied load, the stress mainly comes from bending moments caused by the radial load on the tube which increase linearly with unsupported length. Adding more length doesn’t distribute the load, it just subjects the newly-added material to even more load. The deflection of a beam is proportional to the double integral of the bending moment, which results in a cubic increase in deflection per length.

Or in other words, long unsupported lengths are really bad.

posts.name: יהלי
posts.cooked: great explanation! thanks!

We used Revs Maxspline as a dead axle last year and were pretty happy with it.

Using one of their clamping collars you are able to tie it into surrounding structure in a really robust way.

image 966×797 93.4 KB

image 966×797 93.4 KB

image 966×797 93.4 KB

And any 35mm bearing or bushing should work. We used a bronze bushing from mcmaster , it was a little sloppier than we would have liked but seemed to work fine, ive seen other teams use thin profile 35mm bearings that would probably work better.

posts.name: david
posts.cooked:
A Guide to Designing Robust Robot Arms Technical

This guide is kind of old… and I haven’t updated it in a while.

Okay, but there are many good ways to do this. The main idea is you want to increase the diameter of your tube/whatever and bring the two sides supporting together. Play around with some designs and try posting them and get feedback, but a lot of the examples in this thread/the guide I posted should be “good” enough.

posts.cooked:
Yeah I’m a fan of the tube and bushing method mentioned above. Here’s my former team’s 2018 robot with a decently clear photo of the pivot on the arm.

image 1024×768 92.3 KB

image 1024×768 92.3 KB

image 1024×768 92.3 KB

Large oilite bushings in the rectangular tubing of the frame and the arm, use a 7/8" tube for the axle. Some of your favorite clamping blocks to attach sprockets to, and you’re basically good to go. I used huge clamping collars to keep it all in place that year.

image 768×1024 99.6 KB

image 768×1024 99.6 KB

image 768×1024 99.6 KB

While Rev products can make things easier if you want to go that route, it certainly isn’t needed. Personally I still prefer the clamping blocks such as these from Thrifty Thrifty Clamping Bearing Block as it can allow you to vary your arm lengths and hole locations a bit more. But it all works, we used the Rev spline for our wrist on the 177 2023 robot, we ended up reinforcing the area around where the spline engaged the wrist using these plates: MAXSpline Brackets - REV Robotics

Rev also has these which can allow you to use your own unpatterned tube if you want: MAXSpline Bearing Blocks - REV Robotics

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
Ok, sorry for the delay.

So when designing our arm for 2023 we were very keen to learn the lessons from 2019 where our carriage arm died in just about every way imaginable (twisted hex shaft, shattered VersaPlanetaries, shattered 20DP gears). Your post is specifically about the axle so here’s some our design criteria specifically relating to the dead axle:

Dead axle. This was # 1 on the list. Dead axls transferes the torque to the arm directly rather than indirectly through the shaft, it’s just so much better.

7/8" OD x 1/8" wall round stock instead of hex. Hex shaft is great for many things and maybe could have worked here (relatively short shaft) but alum  tubing has far superior strength in just about every way imaginable.

We chose 7/8" OD tube specifically because the oil embedded bronze bushings you can buy from McMaster for 7/8" shaft are 1.125" OD which fits perfectly with the versakey mounting pattern on FRC COTS sprockets. Bushings work amazing for these sorts of low RPM applications.

Speaking of COTS sprockets, AndyMark now sells these awesome arm sprockets with extra holes specifically designed to mount to 2x1 tubing while retaining the versakey mounting. Fantastic product!

We mounted the tube on either end with 7/8" OD star nuts which turned out to be a bad idea.  While these will work well for fixing the tube in place, they aren’t designed to support the load we were putting on them. We ended ended up replacing these with turned aluminum plugs pressed into each end of the tube.

A perennial issue with dead axel is that it’s inherently harder to measure the rotation of the arm since the shaft isn’t moving, rather the arm moves around the shaft. We opted to bolt a pulley directly to the arm which was geared 1:1 to a hex shaft with a REV through bore encoder. It was a little bit of a pain to assemble but worked super well.

Here’s some pictures of our 2023 arm:
